qas.question: What were Egyptians herding in the early BCE period?
By what time period were the Egyptians constructing  large buildings?
What items replaced previously items made of stone?
In which direction were the dead facing when they were   buried?
Which direction were large buildings built to face?
By what era did occupation of the Al Fayyum end?
What made Egyptian preservation rites difficult?
What diet did Egyptians begin to move away from?

context: By <a1_0>6000 BCE<a1_0/> predynastic Egyptians in the southwestern corner of Egypt were herding <a0_0>cattle<a0_0/> and constructing large buildings. Subsistence in organized and permanent settlements in predynastic Egypt by the middle of the 6th millennium BCE centered predominantly on <b8_0>cereal and animal agriculture<b8_0/>: cattle, goats, pigs and sheep. <a2_0>Metal objects<a2_0/> replaced prior ones of <b4_0>stone<b4_0/>. Tanning of animal skins, pottery and weaving were commonplace in this era also. There are indications of seasonal or only temporary occupation of the Al Fayyum in <b6_0>the 6th millennium<b6_0/> BCE, with food activities centering on fishing, hunting and food-gathering. Stone arrowheads, knives and scrapers from the era are commonly found. Burial items included pottery, jewelry, farming and hunting equipment, and assorted foods including dried meat and fruit. Burial in <b7_0>desert environments<b7_0/> appears to enhance Egyptian preservation rites, and dead were buried facing <a3_0>due <b5_0>west<b5_0/><a3_0/>.
